description: From Middle English injurie, from Anglo-Norman injurie, from Latin iniūria (“injustice; wrong; offense”), from in- (“not”) + iūs, iūris (“right, law”). Doublet of injuria.

entries.meaning: Damage to the body of a living thing.
examples: The passenger sustained a severe injury in the car accident.

entries.meaning: Other forms of damage sustained by a living thing, e.g. psychologically.
The violation of a person's reputation, rights, property, or interests.
examples: Slander is an injury to the character.

verbs.description: injury (third-person singular simple present injuries, present participle injurying, simple past and past participle injuried)

examples: The best of us doth not so much feare to wrong him, as he doth to injurie his neighbour, his kinsman, or his master.
